DIALOGUE BEFORE: Chase: Simply put: They want to kill each other, and each side wants us to help them.
RESPONSE TEXT: We've tried to stay neutral, but Far Harbor was going to be wiped out by the Fog, so that's when we built the Condensers for them.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: And I was friends with the previous leader of the Children of Atom, Confessor Martin. I even gave them their headquarters, the submarine base they named the Nucleus.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking to the player, who has persuaded DiMA to tell you about what's going on

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DiMA: He's been threatening us, to force us to choose a side. I left behind something very important in that submarine base I gave them.
RESPONSE TEXT: DiMA's earliest memories are stored in the military computer banks in that base. The prewar security systems and Confessor Martin's good will were supposed to keep them safe.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Chase: But now Tektus is in charge, and he's after DiMA's memories. We don't even know what's in them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Chase: You'll have to get through the Children of Atom's base. You're new on the island, so you might be able to pose as a recruit.
RESPONSE TEXT: Then once you get to the memory banks, you'll have to use a special program DiMA and I have been working on to break through the security systems.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: It's not going to be like a normal hack. You'll be breaking through a version of my own mental network. It'll consider you to be an intruder.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Chase: They're going to kill each other, DiMA. There's no stopping it. We need to pick a side now.
RESPONSE TEXT: Haven't we already picked a side? Building the Fog Condensers around Far Harbor wasn't exactly a neutral act.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: We couldn't stand by and let the people of this island die to the Fog.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Chase: Well the new Confessor isn't. "High Confessor" Tektus is an unstable megalomaniac and he's going to keep threatening us as long as we're helping Far Harbor.
RESPONSE TEXT: Guys. Can we talk about the elephant in the room? We keep dancing around it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: My old memory banks in the submarine base.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DiMA: We can't risk it. They know you're from Acadia. If you're caught or even seen, then it's war.
RESPONSE TEXT: We should at least prepare her to go in. We're running out of options. I say we tell her how to crack into the memory banks.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Chase: You've been working on this without me?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DiMA: I've loaded the program with some instructions I've recorded that will help guide you through it. I'm afraid it's difficult to explain without seeing it for yourself.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm finishing up some tweaks to the program right now. I'll leave a copy of it for you on my desk when I'm done.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Chase: Get the program. Use it to break into the memory banks. Got it.
SCRIPT NOTES: to Chase, explaining where she can get the program

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not even going to complain that you've been snooping around in terminals, all right? I know how this looks.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: You have to understand, we did the best we could.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Faraday: I'm not even going to complain that you've been snooping around in terminals, all right? I know how this looks.
RESPONSE TEXT: You have to understand, we did the best we could.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You saved her life. Nothing matters as much as that does.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You saved her life. Nothing matters as much as that does.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's no excuse for leaving her in the state she's in.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: You... You already told her, didn't you? That's why she won't come back in, why she won't look me in the eye.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: You... You already told her, didn't you? That's why she won't come back in, why she won't look me in the eye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Can you just tell me what happened?
RESPONSE TEXT: The boat crashed, she was beyond injured. We did what we could, but the only way to get her past the trauma was to try a wipe.
I don't have Institute-level technology here. There were complications. And now... Well, now she's Jule. She's broken, but she's alive.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: You... You already told her, didn't you? That's why she won't come back in, why she won't look me in the eye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Tecchnically, yes. But... the side-effects... I swear to you, I wanted better for her. I really did.

Well, I'm in no position to judge, I suppose. But I really do wonder whether that was the right thing.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Tecchnically, yes. But... the side-effects... I swear to you, I wanted better for her. I really did.
RESPONSE TEXT: Do me a favor: don't say anything to her. I can live with the guilt; she shouldn't have to.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I've got those storage drives you asked for.
RESPONSE TEXT: Me? I don't know why you'd care... I escaped the Institute, just like others here. Never had my mind wiped, thankfully.
I like to think I came along right when DiMA needed me. I found him before all this, before Acadia. He needed my help, though he refused to admit it.
He's always been stubborn like that. Anyway, I've been by his side ever since, making sure he has everything he needs.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I've got those storage drives you asked for.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Sorry, never mind.
RESPONSE TEXT: Okay...
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: Oh, that's great! Thank you... Uhh... Just the two? Really? I somehow thought there were three...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I know what you did to Jule, Faraday.
RESPONSE TEXT: What? Oh... Oh no. Okay, look...
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: I'm not even going to complain that you've been snooping around in terminals, all right? I know how this looks.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I know what you did to Jule, Faraday.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, that's certainly an understatement. Between the two of us, we've made so many modifications...
He was just a prototype, never built for all this. It took a lot to overcome the limitations of the original design and expand his memory.
It really is remarkable, isn't it? He's overcome so much... he's become so much more than he once was. And all he thinks of is others.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I've got those storage drives you asked for.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Can you tell me about the Fog Condensers?
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, those? DiMA and I designed them when it became clear the fog was only getting worse. They're effective, but have such a limited range.
DiMA insisted we provide them to the people of Far Harbor, and I'm so glad we did. Without the condensers, I'm not sure they'd have anywhere left.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I've got those storage drives you asked for.

RESPONSE TEXT: You were in there a long time... are you feeling all right?
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: I'm fine. You worry too much.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DiMA: I'm fine. You worry too much.
RESPONSE TEXT: Sometimes I feel like you don't worry enough. You know we blew three more relays this week.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: I'm coming in. You stay right there.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Faraday: I'm coming in. You stay right there.
RESPONSE TEXT: I was having a hard enough time keeping up with repairs before all this nonsense with the Atom lunatics.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DiMA: They're nothing you need to be concerned about.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DiMA: They're nothing you need to be concerned about.
RESPONSE TEXT: It's not them... I'm concerned about you, DiMA. You can't solve all the world's problems, certainly not all at once.

RESPONSE TEXT: Urgh.
No...
Ungh.
Argh.
Oh dear, did I confuse you?

Are we done talking, then? I'm confused.
So, you've talked to DiMA. You know why we're here.

RESPONSE TEXT: With DiMA gone, I'm not even sure what the point of all this is anymore.
Acadia's just never going to be the same without DiMA running things.
My job was always taking care of DiMA... What is there left for me now?
I know DiMA is convinced there was no other choice, but... an entire town gone? Because of us? It's hard to stomach.
If only something could've been done to prevent tragedy in Far Harbor.
So much death... Acadia is safer, but at what cost? Was it really all worth it?
I hate that it came to having to make decisions over who lives and dies. The Children of Atom deserved better. We all do.
I wish there had been some way to reconcile with the Children of Atom.
I know you played a big role in ratcheting down the tension on the island, and I'm grateful.
DiMA gave his life to broker peace with Far Harbor. Now they're gone... and what the hell does any of it mean?
I still can't believe DiMA's gone. He'd already done so much, and then to give up his own life for ours...
DiMA needs near-constant monitoring. I'm the only one qualified.
I'm really very busy right now.
Wait, what?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Faraday: You - you can't! DiMA, if you go down there, you're not coming back up!
